chapter.heading: CONFIDENTIALITY OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEER SUPPORT COUNSELING

content.p: The term “law enforcement agency” means a Federal agency that employs a law enforcement officer.
The term “law enforcement officer” has the meaning given the term “Federal law enforcement officer” in section 115 of title 18.

subparagraph.content: an oral or written communication made in the course of a peer support counseling session;
a note or report arising out of a peer support counseling session;
a record of a peer support counseling session; or

subparagraph.chapeau: with respect to a communication made by a peer support participant in the course of a peer support counseling session, another communication, regarding the first communication, that is made between a peer support specialist and—

clause.content: a staff member of a peer support counseling program; or
a supervisor of the peer support specialist.

content.p: The term “peer support counseling program” means a program provided by a law enforcement agency that provides counseling services from a peer support specialist to a law enforcement officer of the agency.
The term “peer support counseling session” means any counseling formally provided through a peer support counseling program between a peer support specialist and 1 or more law enforcement officers.
The term “peer support participant” means a law enforcement officer who receives counseling services from a peer support specialist.

paragraph.heading: Peer support specialist
paragraph.chapeau: The term “peer support specialist” means a law enforcement officer who—

clause.content: providing emotional and moral support to law enforcement officers who have been involved in or exposed to an emotionally traumatic experience in the course of employment; and

subparagraph.content: is designated by a law enforcement agency to provide the services described in subparagraph (A).

content.p: Except as provided in subsection (c), a peer support specialist or a peer support participant may not disclose the contents of a peer support communication to an individual who was not a party to the peer support communication.

subsection.heading: Exceptions
subsection.chapeau: Subsection (b) shall not apply to a peer support communication if—

subparagraph.chapeau: an explicit threat of suicide by an individual in which the individual—

subclause.content: an intent to die by suicide; and
a plan for a suicide attempt or the means by which the individual plans to carry out a suicide attempt; and

clause.content: does not solely share that the individual is experiencing suicidal thoughts;

subparagraph.content: an explicit threat by an individual of imminent and serious physical bodily harm or death to another individual;

clause.chapeau: relating to the abuse or neglect of—

subclause.content: an older or vulnerable individual; or

clause.content: that is required by law to be reported; or

paragraph.chapeau: the disclosure is permitted by each peer support participant who was a party to, as applicable—

subparagraph.content: the peer support counseling session out of which the peer support communication arose;
the peer support counseling session of which the peer support communication is a record; or
the communication made in the course of a peer support counseling session that the peer support communication is regarding;

paragraph.content: a court of competent jurisdiction issues an order or subpoena requiring the disclosure of the peer support communication; or
the peer support communication contains information that is required by law to be disclosed.

subsection.heading: Rule of construction
subsection.chapeau: Nothing in subsection (b) shall be construed to prohibit the disclosure of—

paragraph.content: an observation made by a law enforcement officer of a peer support participant outside of a peer support counseling session; or
knowledge of a law enforcement officer about a peer support participant not gained from a peer support communication.

content.p: Before the initial peer support counseling session of a peer support participant, a peer support specialist shall inform the peer support participant in writing of the confidentiality requirement under subsection (b) and the exceptions to the requirement under subsection (c).
The term “first responder” has the meaning given the term “public safety officer” in section 10284 of this title.
The term “first responder agency” means a Federal, State, local, or Tribal agency that employs or otherwise engages the services of a first responder.

The term “peer support counseling program” means a program provided by a first responder agency that provides counseling services from a peer support specialist to a first responder of the first responder agency.
The term “peer support participant” means a first responder who receives counseling services from a peer support specialist.

paragraph.heading: Peer support specialist
paragraph.chapeau: The term “peer support specialist” means a first responder who—

clause.content: providing emotional and moral support to first responders who have been involved in or exposed to an emotionally traumatic experience in the course of the duties of those first responders; and

subparagraph.content: is designated by a first responder agency to provide the services described in subparagraph (A).

subsection.heading: Report on best practices
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 2 years after November 18, 2021, the Attorney General, in coordination with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall develop a report on best practices and professional standards for peer support counseling programs for first responder agencies that includes—

subparagraph.content: establishing and operating peer support counseling programs; and
training and certifying peer support specialists;

paragraph.content: a code of ethics for peer support specialists;
recommendations for continuing education for peer support specialists;
advice on disclosing to first responders any confidentiality rights of peer support participants; and

subparagraph.content: the different types of peer support counseling programs in use by first responder agencies;
any differences in peer support counseling programs offered across categories of first responders; and
the important role senior first responders play in supporting access to mental health resources.

subsection.heading: Implementation
subsection.chapeau: The Attorney General shall support and encourage the implementation of peer support counseling programs in first responder agencies by—

paragraph.content: making the report developed under subsection (b) publicly available on the website of the Department of Justice; and
providing a list of peer support specialist training programs on the website of the Department of Justice.
